subject: Re: I'd like to be able to write the prefixes com- and con- as contractions
msgSnippet: Good thought. It doesn t confuse the sound of a QS character as would be the case if using owe in kom- kon-.
messageBody:
Good thought. It doesn't confuse the sound of a QS character as would be the case if using owe in kom- kon-.


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, BPJ <bpj@...> wrote:
>
> On 2011-08-18 18:12, cossyrosario wrote:
> > What I have been using as an even shorter work-around for
> > temporary private notes (to-do list, notes of a meeting discussion
> > to be transcribed fairly soon on the computer) is just the k as a
> > prefix, thus kputer for computer, kshus for conscious, etc.
>
> I always do that too, since that's what I've been doing
> in Shorthand for 20+ years. It can hardly be misunderstood
> in context, at least if what follows begins with a consonant
> other than R/L/Y/W. In those cases you can safely write KN-
> (with reverse N) and KM-, since those can not occur word-
> initially in English (K is mute where they occur in TO).
>
> /bpj
>
